Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: EAGER: MITATE: Mobile Internet Testbed for Application Traffic Experimentation

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project creates a Mobile Internet Testbed for Application Traffic Experimentation (MITATE) - a large-scale mobile application prototyping platform. MITATE will enable developers to evaluate protocol design choices, application deployment alternatives, and component mobility mechanisms - all in live mobile networks spanning geographic areas, carriers, and devices. MITATE will also benefit the computing research community by lowering the barrier to experimentation on mobile devices in production networks.

MITATE allows experimentation with custom mobile application traffic between mobile devices and cloud infrastructure endpoints, on which application back-end logic is deployed. MITATE is designed as a collaborative framework, in which participants contribute their mobile network resources and are allowed, in turn, to run their traffic experiments on others devices. The MITATE design, specifically the tit-for-tat data credit system and the separation of traffic generation functionality from application logic, will ensure safe and self-scaling testbed operation. This testbed will enable novel and compelling research at Montana State University on self-optimizing low latency protocols.

Performance_Institution.Name: Montana State University, Computer Science Dept.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project aimed to improve the understanding of the performance of production 3G and 4G cellular networks as experienced by client devices. Of particular interest were the impact of network performance on application performance - specifically interactive services and mobile content delivery. Because net neutrality rules to not, in general, apply to mobile networks, the providers of these networks are free to shape client traffic to provide adequate network performance to all users. We were interested in understanding whether these traffic shaping practices affect web and mobile application performance in these networks in practice.

 

To support network measurement we developed the MITATE cellular experimentation testbed. The code for the tool is open-sourced and available at  https://github.com/msu-netlab/MITATE. MITATE is the first collaborative cellular measurement platform that incorporates incentives for participation as well as active measurements using custom traffic patterns. Using MITATE we were able to show the cases when traffic shaping takes place in mobile networks and its impact on network applications.

 

We have also partnered with Akamai, the world's largest Content Delivery Network (CDN), on several projects to use use their widely distributed infrastructure to measure and speed up Web content delivery in cellular networks. We have disseminated these results via several high-profile venues among the network measurement and web performance communities.



 


Last Modified: 06/24/2019
Modified by: Mike P Wittie
